Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Cloud-based Acoustic Simulation Service
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop new ways of using cloud computing to accurately model acoustics in buildings. Reliably modeling the behavior of sound waves is a difficult problem. Researchers have recently developed an algorithm called Adaptive Rectangular Decomposition (ARD), which can accurately model acoustics. But given the amount of memory and processing power found in desktop and laptop computers today, ARD can only work on small buildings or for low frequencies. The only way to make ARD work in complex, real-world situations is to run it on multiple computers at the same time, by moving it to the cloud. ARD is based on mathematical techniques that make it difficult to scale in the cloud. This is because individual computers (or compute nodes) must keep sending data to each other, slowing down the overall simulation. In this project, the company will develop new algorithms to carefully manage this data exchange and evenly distribute the simulation work across multiple compute nodes. This will allow much faster acoustic simulation. It will also make it practical to reliably model the acoustics of large spaces for all audible sound frequencies.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project touches many aspects of architectural design. The cloud-based acoustic simulation service (CBASS) is aimed at architects and acoustical consultants. There are more than 105,000 architects, 17,500 architecture firms, and 2,000 acoustical consultants in the US. Acoustic simulation is a $2.3 billion market. CBASS will be used to understand the acoustics of a building before it is built, reducing the time and money spent on fixing acoustic issues. By running in the cloud, CBASS will also reduce the need for architects and acoustical consultants to buy costly computers, and will let them run and monitor simulations using laptops, tablets, or smartphones. It will also speed up the architectural design process. We will offer free subscriptions to CBASS to students; this will help train the next generation of architects to think about acoustics at an earlier point in the design phase. More generally, increased use of acoustic simulation will lead to better sounding spaces for everyone: classrooms that are more conducive to learning, hospitals that more conducive to healing, more enjoyable theaters, and quieter homes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project resulted in the development of new ways of using cloud computing to accurately model acoustics in buildings. The Cloud-Based Acoustic Simulation Service (CBASS) developed during this project is aimed at architects and acoustical consultants. Acoustic simulation is $2.3 billion market, with 105,000 architects, 17,500 architecture firms, and 2,000 acoustical consultants in the US. CBASS will be used to better understand the acoustics of a building before it is built, reducing the cost of fixing acoustic issues. By running in the cloud, CBASS will help make architects and acoustical consultants more productive, collaborate better on design projects, and reduce the need for them to buy costly computers.

Researchers have recently developed an algorithm called Adaptive Rectangular Decomposition (ARD), which can accurately model acoustics. The only way to make ARD work in complex, real-world situations, though, is to run it on multiple computers at the same time, by moving it to the cloud. ARD is based on mathematical techniques that make it difficult to scale in the cloud, because individual computers (nodes) must keep sending data to each other, slowing down the overall simulation.

During this project, we developed an algorithm for evenly distributing the simulation workload across multiple computers. This is not as easy as it sounds, due to the way ARD works. This “load balancing” process is mathematically very complicated, and we have devised an algorithm for solving it. Through experiments, we have shown that our algorithm distributes the workload very evenly. This would not be possible without the careful algorithm design enabled by this Phase I project.

We also developed an algorithm for taking the distributed simulation workload and actually running the acoustic simulation. The main design goal for this algorithm was to carefully manage the data exchange between computers. This was done by designing the algorithm to continue running simulation calculations while the data transfer happens in the background. This process, called “latency hiding”, results in much faster simulations. It also allows CBASS to scale in the cloud: assigning more computers to the simulation causes the simulation to run faster.

We also measured the ability of our algorithms to scale in the cloud. These measurements were taken on university-owned compute resources, as well as on Microsoft’s Azure platform for cloud computing. These measurements have shown that our algorithms scale well on large simulations, due to the even work distribution, and careful management of data exchange between computers. The measurements have also helped identify certain areas for further research. One example is that requesting additional computers in the cloud and including them in the simulation is a time-consuming process.

Finally, we also demonstrated that our work distribution algorithm does not cause a lot of error in the simulation results. Due to the nature of ARD, dividing simulation work may lead to a buildup of error in the results. We carefully designed our work distribution algorithm to reduce this error buildup.

Over the course of this Phase I project, we developed algorithms that allow CBASS to scale efficiently and reliably in the cloud. This will allow architects and acoustical consultants to perform much faster acoustic simulation. It will also make it practical to reliably model the acoustics of large spaces for all audible sound frequencies.
